text: England is just a great neighborhood
it's like a little town in the Dominican
Republic or Puerto Rico with parks to
hang out restaurants to go and eat I
really love the dichotomy between parks
and forests and water and the charming
grit of New York City geographically in
wood is quite beautiful
lots and lots of water views the East
River the Harlem River the Harlem River
shipping canal and of course the Hudson
River we have over 200 acres of parks
the smaller park is Isham Park which
some of the neighborhood people call
circle Park and then we have Inwood Hill
Park which is original growth forest
there's a rock there that has is the
site where supposedly Manhattan was
bought from the Native Americans
you got these views of the Hudson bridge
and there are baseball fields from this
part of Inwood you've got the a train of
the one train
you've got access to express buses that
go down the east side as well as the
west side and it's about an eight minute
walk to Metro North Station at Marble
Hill you know it's far but not as far as
you think
another advantage was because we're at
the northern tip of Manhattan if you
want to get away for the weekend you get
out really quickly where we're sitting
now for five hundred years ago was a
seasonal Native American fishing village
it was Dutch when it was settled and
then it was very Irish neighborhood and
then in the 70s it started changing and
a lot of the Irish immigrants left and a
lot of Dominicans moved in my wife and I
moved here in December of 1981 it was
then a dangerous neighborhood and then
little by little the neighborhood began
to change you know we've got the whole
daikon Renaissance
on Dyckman Street is now a huge hub of
restaurants but you can see the
Dominican influence everywhere really
the farmers market was not a thing when
we first moved in the first weekend they
came they sold out all of their goods in
like two hours and so now that market is
year round I think the challenge here
there's a bit of a dividing line along
Broadway west of Broadway you're going
to have more home ownership you're going
to have stable housing stock and then on
the east side of Broadway you'll find
that they're far more renters you also
find that there's an ethnic division and
the largely Dominican a Dominican
American population lives east of
Broadway if you live west of Broadway
you're zoned for slightly better schools
and it's terrible I hate that part of it
public education was always a difficulty
we had the worst course for decades
it's beginning to change a bit but that
that's a challenge that the neighborhood
and the neighbors have had to face for a
very long time
I think that the neighborhood is still
affordable in the early 90s I was
attracted to the neighborhood because
the apartments were not chopped up into
smaller apartments because real estate
didn't go sky-high rapidly like it did
in other parts of the city many of the
apartments have very high ceilings they
have sunken living rooms they're just
very comfortable we kind of joke up here
that were just this side of cool like
they're all these trendy neighborhoods
and we feel like we're almost there and
then for some reason something doesn't
quite push us over the edge which is not
necessarily a bad thing because I think
it's keeping things still more
affordable and keeping that sense of
community we wanted to be in a place
where we could meet different people and
have different experiences taste
different wines eat different foods and
be part of different cultures you know
and so that's why you know at least me
my husband we really want to stay here
as long as we can
Oh
